title: NetBackup for VMware best practices
url: https://www.veritas.com/support/en_US/doc/21902280-161976672-0/v19546127-161976672
collection_title: NetBackup™ for VMware Administrator's Guide
product_version: ['10.3', '10.2', '10.1.1', '10.1']
## NetBackup for VMware best practices

The following are best practices for NetBackup for VMware:

  * For a more efficient backup, the NetBackup media server and the VMware backup host should be installed on the same host. * When creating virtual machines, use the same name for both host name and display name. If the policy's Primary VM identifier option is changed, the existing entries on the policy Clients tab still work. * VMware recommends that you run no more than four simultaneous backups of virtual machines that reside on the same datastore. * Successful VMware snapshots depend on the following:

    * The amount of I/O that occurs on the virtual machine datastore. Backups should be scheduled when relatively little I/O activity is expected. Reducing the number of simultaneous backups can also help. Limit access to the datastore per policy: Use the Limit jobs per policy
attribute in the NetBackup policy. Limit access to the datastore globally (across all policies): Use the Host
Properties Resource Limit screen. See [Setting global limits on the use of VMware resources](v47183490 "Setting
global limits on the use of VMware resources"). * The design of the I/O substructure that is associated with each virtual machine datastore. For correct I/O design and implementation, consult your VMware documentation. * Make sure that the VMware backup host has enough memory to handle the number of simultaneous backups that occur. * Include in a single NetBackup policy those virtual machines that use the same datastore. This practice lets you control the amount of backup-related I/O that occurs per datastore, to limit the backup effect on the target virtual machines. * NetBackup supports multiple backup hosts. When a single backup host is saturated with a backup process, another backup host can be added to increase backup throughput. * If a VM's disks are accessible to multiple ESX hosts, the disks can be accessed for backup or restore through any of the ESX hosts. The ESX host may or may not be the ESX host where the virtual machine is running or registered. All of the following must be accessible to each other and should have DNS configured:

    * The vCenter server. * All ESX hosts under the vCenter that have access to the VM's vmdk files.

title: VMware with Accelerator backups experiencing performance issues
url: https://www.veritas.com/support/en_US/article.100032433.html
The Accelerator option is synthesizing a Full VMware backup when
an Incremental is executed, and multiple reads of previous backups are slow
because they have to read from many different containers. The use of encryption had a contributing effect, and was originally thought to
be the main effect, but tests in a lab proved otherwise. This is thought to be tied to the initial backups, since most of the VMs in
this environment were deployed from the same few templates, so data change was
actually fairly low, but because the initial backups included 96 jobs all at
once, it was impossible to contain SOs from spreading across containers while
so many jobs were running at once. Reduce the occurrence of bad Segment
Locality with the following initial backup procedures when setting up VMware
with Accelerator  backups to PDDE (Deduplication storage):

  1. Review the VMs in the environment and determine what OS / Application are the majority of the VMs. Determine the top 5 to 10 *types* of VM. (If using templates, determine which is the most often deployed manually). This task is unfortunately time consuming if this data point is not already being tracked. It is not immediately available as a metric in VSphere. 2. Find one example VM from each of the types, determined in the previous step. 3. Create a simple VMware policy, with manual client selection and backup the first example ONLY--(ONE Virtual Machine in the policy). **It is critical to this solution that only one (1) job run to PDDE at any given moment until this procedure is complete. By running a single job, the data is filtered through PDPlugin and then sent to Deduplication Storage one SO at a time, sequentially filling up containers from a single backup, ensuring that the SO's for at least one image are all adjacent. Since this has a high degree of commonality with other VMs in the environment, this data will be referenced extensively, and we will benefit during reads since a large amount of the data will be adjacent and contiguous. 4. Repeat for each client; do not start a new backup until the previous is complete. The initial Deduplication rates will increase on subsequent jobs and is not the goal at this point. The current goal is to "seed" the PDDE storage with single contiguous data streams. 5. When the last VM determined from step 2 above has completed its backup, this procedure is complete, and backups can be started according to either VMware Intelligent Policy, or multiple manually selected clients without issue with the Accelerator feature enabled with as many jobs and clients at once that is appropriate for the PDDE storage unit in the environment. 

title: HotAdd transport mode requirements for VMware VM backups
url: https://www.veritas.com/support/en_US/article.100046069.html
#### HotAdd transport mode requirements for VMware VM backups

It is suggested to consider the below options before using HotAdd transport
mode to backup and restore VMs. * The backup host VM must be created from the scratch (Not from any template or cannot be a clone of any VM). * The backup host VM must reside under the same data center where the VM to backup exist. * The backup host VM must have enough number of SCSI controllers to accommodate VMDKs from other VMs to be mounted. * Maximum 4 SCSI controllers can be attached to one backup host VM. A single SCSI controller can have a maximum of 15 disks attached. * HotAdd works only with virtual machines with SCSI disks and is not supported for backing up virtual machines with IDE disks. * To run multiple concurrent jobs totally for more than 15 disks, it is necessary to add more SCSI controllers to the HotAdd host. The maximum number of 4 SCSI controllers can be added to a HotAdd host, so a total of 60 devices are supported at the maximum. * HotAdd requires the VMware Backup Host to have access to datastores where the Virtual Machine being backed up resides. This essentially means: ESX where the VMware backup host is running should have access to datastores where the Virtual Machine being backed up resides. * HotAdd cannot be used if the VMFS block size of the datastore containing the virtual machine folder for the target virtual machine does not match the VMFS block size of the datastore containing the VMware Backup Host virtual machine. * For example, if you back up virtual disk on a datastore with 1MB blocks, the VMware Backup Host must also be on a datastore with 1MB blocks. * Restores using HotAdd on a Windows Server 2008 and above proxy require setting the SAN policy to OnlineAll. * If we are converting a physical machine to a virtual machine with the intention of using HotAdd to back up the virtual machine, do not use IDE controllers for any disks that are used during the conversion process. * The VMware backup host will need the ability to connect to TCP port 443 on the vCenter and TCP ports 443 and 902 on ESX/ESXi hosts while using HotAdd for backup/restores.

    * The amount of I/O that occurs on the virtual machine datastore. Backups should be scheduled when relatively little I/O activity is expected. Reducing the number of simultaneous backups can also help. Limit access to the datastore per policy: Use the Limit jobs per policy
attribute in the NetBackup policy. Limit access to the datastore globally (across all policies): Use the Host

title: VMware with Accelerator backups experiencing performance issues
url: https://www.veritas.com/support/en_US/article.100032433.html
Accelerator optimization is not impacted, however the jobs take
more time to complete overall. **BPBKAR log** from the Linux VMware backup
host (a Windows VMware backup host does not capture these messages in the
BPBKAR log):

  `<4> vxms_shutdown: VxMS Performance stats: (../vxms_bridge.cpp:971)...<4>
vxms_shutdown: **FIML ReadOnly Time: 71910514280** , Size: 6057328640, Ops:
70645, **MB/s: 80.332** (../vxms_bridge.cpp:992)<4> vxms_shutdown: **ACCL
Checksum Time: 169154432** , Size: 15761408, Ops: 130, **MB/s: 88.8611**
(../vxms_bridge.cpp:994)<4> vxms_shutdown: **FIML Total Read Time:
72079668712** , Size: 6073090048, Ops: 70775, **MB/s:
80.3521**(../vxms_bridge.cpp:998)<4> vxms_shutdown: **FIML Write Time:
26070366911696** , Size: 6057328640, Ops: 70645, **MB/s: 0.221582**
(../vxms_bridge.cpp:1004)`

Note here that the read time is not the problem, but **BPBKAR** appears to be
waiting on **BPTM** , indicating a delay committing write operations. Segment Object (SO) spread (more SO's spread across more containers, also
know as Segment Locality) results in poor reads since they cannot be
optimized.


```

# Question
```
How many VMware vms can I back up at the same time on the same datastore?
```

content.text: VMware recommends that you run no more than four simultaneous backups of virtual machines that reside on the same datastore.

waiting on **BPTM** , indicating a delay committing write operations. Segment Object (SO) spread (more SO's spread across more containers, also
know as Segment Locality) results in poor reads since they cannot be
optimized.

for all hosts. _ErrorCodes(s)/Message(s)_ : None  
  
 _Troubleshooting_ :  The admin,bpjava-msvc, and bpjava-susvc logs will not
show anyerrors. _Resolution_ :  
  
Disabling IP lookup for the javaconsole can resolve this issue. This disables
the resolution of host namesto IP addresses, for the purpose of determining if
host names areequivalent. 1) Shut down the Javaadministration console.

# Question
```
How do I export the host properties from the admin console?
```

content.text:
To export the host properties from the NetBackup Administration Console, follow these steps:

1. In the NetBackup Administration Console, expand **NetBackup Management > Host Properties > Primary Servers**, **Media Servers**, or **Clients**.
2. Select a host. If you want to select multiple hosts, hold down the **Shift** key and select another host.
3. Click **File > Export**.
4. In the Export dialog box, name the file, browse to the directory where you want to save it, and click **Save**.

# Question
```
How do I export the host properties from the admin console?
```

# Reference answer
```
In the NetBackup Administration Console, expand NetBackup Management > Host Properties > Primary Servers, Media Servers, or Clients.
Select a host. If you want to select multiple hosts, hold down the Shift key and select another host.
Click File > Export.
In the Export dialog box, name the file, browse to the directory where you want to save it, and click Save
```

```

title: Appliance Entry Remains in EMM After Running nbdecommission Command
url: https://www.veritas.com/support/en_US/article.100046070.html
Attempting to run **nbemmcmd -deletehost** with
**-machinetype appliance** does not remove the appliance entry from the EMM
database. `nbemmcmd -listhosts`

**Example output:**

`NBEMMCMD, Version: 8.1.1  
The following hosts were found:  
server            nbmaster1  
master            nbmaster1  
ndmp              nbmaster1  
**appliance         nbappliance**  
Command completed successfully.`

The appliance continues to remain configured as a device in EMM after the
decommission attempt and cannot be deleted from the EMM database until removed
as a device host. To clean up the appliance entry in EMM, first run **tpconfig** to delete the
appliance entry:

`tpconfig -delete -nb_appliance **nbappliance**`

Once the device is removed, you can now run **nbemmcmd** to delete the host
from EMM:

`nbemmcmd -deletehost -machinename **nbappliance** -machinetype appliance`

Check EMM database for the entry:

`nbemmcmd -listhosts`



**Example outputs from lab:**

`# nbdecommission -oldserver **nbmedia01** -newserver
nbmedia02.veritas.lab.com -machinetype media`

`# nbemmcmd -deletehost -machinename **nbmedia01** -machinetype ndmp  
NBEMMCMD, Version: 8.1  
Command completed successfully. `

`# nbemmcmd -deletehost -machinename **nbmedia01** -machinetype appliance  
NBEMMCMD, Version: 8.1  
The function returned the following failure status:  
generic EMM SQL error (193)  
Command did not complete successfully.`

To resolve the following commands were ran:

`# tpconfig -delete -nb_appliance **nbmedia01**`

`# nbemmcmd -deletehost -machinename **nbmedia01** -machinetype appliance  
NBEMMCMD, Version: 8.1  
Command completed successfully.`

`# nbemmcmd -listhosts | grep **nbmedia01**`

_(The appliance entry does not return, as it has been successfully removed.)_

**Note** : The tpconfig and nbemmcmd commands are in the following location... * UNIX/Linux:  
`/usr/openv/volmgr/bin/tpconfig  
/usr/openv/netbackup/bin/admincmd/nbemmcmd`

  * Windows:  
`_install_path_ \Veritas\Volmgr\bin\tpconfig.exe  
_install_path_ \Veritas\NetBackup\bin\admincmd\nbemmcmd.exe`






```

# Question
```
How do I remove a device host from the EMM Database from admin console?
```

content.text:
To remove a device host from the EMM database using the NetBackup Administration Console, follow these steps:

1. In the NetBackup Administration Console, in the left pane, expand Media and Device Management > Devices > Media Servers.
2. Select the host you wish to remove.
3. On the Actions menu, select Enterprise Media Manager Database > Remove Device Host.
4. Click Yes in the confirmation dialog box.

title: Appliance Entry Remains in EMM After Running nbdecommission Command
url: https://www.veritas.com/support/en_US/article.100046070.html
Attempting to run **nbemmcmd -deletehost** with
**-machinetype appliance** does not remove the appliance entry from the EMM
database. `nbemmcmd -listhosts`

**Example output:**

`NBEMMCMD, Version: 8.1.1  
The following hosts were found:  
server            nbmaster1  
master            nbmaster1  
ndmp              nbmaster1  
**appliance         nbappliance**  
Command completed successfully.`

The appliance continues to remain configured as a device in EMM after the
decommission attempt and cannot be deleted from the EMM database until removed
as a device host. To clean up the appliance entry in EMM, first run **tpconfig** to delete the
appliance entry:

`tpconfig -delete -nb_appliance **nbappliance**`

Once the device is removed, you can now run **nbemmcmd** to delete the host
from EMM:

`nbemmcmd -deletehost -machinename **nbappliance** -machinetype appliance`

Check EMM database for the entry:

`nbemmcmd -listhosts`



**Example outputs from lab:**

`# nbdecommission -oldserver **nbmedia01** -newserver
nbmedia02.veritas.lab.com -machinetype media`

`# nbemmcmd -deletehost -machinename **nbmedia01** -machinetype ndmp  
NBEMMCMD, Version: 8.1  
Command completed successfully. `

`# nbemmcmd -deletehost -machinename **nbmedia01** -machinetype appliance  
NBEMMCMD, Version: 8.1  
The function returned the following failure status:  
generic EMM SQL error (193)  
Command did not complete successfully.`

To resolve the following commands were ran:

`# tpconfig -delete -nb_appliance **nbmedia01**`

`# nbemmcmd -deletehost -machinename **nbmedia01** -machinetype appliance  
NBEMMCMD, Version: 8.1  
Command completed successfully.`

`# nbemmcmd -listhosts | grep **nbmedia01**`

_(The appliance entry does not return, as it has been successfully removed.)_

**Note** : The tpconfig and nbemmcmd commands are in the following location... * UNIX/Linux:  
`/usr/openv/volmgr/bin/tpconfig  
/usr/openv/netbackup/bin/admincmd/nbemmcmd`

  * Windows:  
`_install_path_ \Veritas\Volmgr\bin\tpconfig.exe  
_install_path_ \Veritas\NetBackup\bin\admincmd\nbemmcmd.exe`

title: NetBackup for VMware best practices
url: https://www.veritas.com/support/en_US/doc/21902280-161976672-0/v19546127-161976672
collection_title: NetBackup™ for VMware Administrator's Guide
product_version: ['10.3', '10.2', '10.1.1', '10.1']
## NetBackup for VMware best practices

The following are best practices for NetBackup for VMware:

  * For a more efficient backup, the NetBackup media server and the VMware backup host should be installed on the same host. * When creating virtual machines, use the same name for both host name and display name. If the policy's Primary VM identifier option is changed, the existing entries on the policy Clients tab still work. * VMware recommends that you run no more than four simultaneous backups of virtual machines that reside on the same datastore. * Successful VMware snapshots depend on the following:

    * The amount of I/O that occurs on the virtual machine datastore. Backups should be scheduled when relatively little I/O activity is expected. Reducing the number of simultaneous backups can also help. Limit access to the datastore per policy: Use the Limit jobs per policy
attribute in the NetBackup policy. Limit access to the datastore globally (across all policies): Use the Host
Properties Resource Limit screen. See [Setting global limits on the use of VMware resources](v47183490 "Setting
global limits on the use of VMware resources"). * The design of the I/O substructure that is associated with each virtual machine datastore. For correct I/O design and implementation, consult your VMware documentation. * Make sure that the VMware backup host has enough memory to handle the number of simultaneous backups that occur. * Include in a single NetBackup policy those virtual machines that use the same datastore. This practice lets you control the amount of backup-related I/O that occurs per datastore, to limit the backup effect on the target virtual machines. * NetBackup supports multiple backup hosts. When a single backup host is saturated with a backup process, another backup host can be added to increase backup throughput. * If a VM's disks are accessible to multiple ESX hosts, the disks can be accessed for backup or restore through any of the ESX hosts. The ESX host may or may not be the ESX host where the virtual machine is running or registered. All of the following must be accessible to each other and should have DNS configured:

    * The vCenter server. * All ESX hosts under the vCenter that have access to the VM's vmdk files.

title: VMware with Accelerator backups experiencing performance issues
url: https://www.veritas.com/support/en_US/article.100032433.html
The Accelerator option is synthesizing a Full VMware backup when
an Incremental is executed, and multiple reads of previous backups are slow
because they have to read from many different containers. The use of encryption had a contributing effect, and was originally thought to
be the main effect, but tests in a lab proved otherwise. This is thought to be tied to the initial backups, since most of the VMs in
this environment were deployed from the same few templates, so data change was
actually fairly low, but because the initial backups included 96 jobs all at
once, it was impossible to contain SOs from spreading across containers while
so many jobs were running at once. Reduce the occurrence of bad Segment
Locality with the following initial backup procedures when setting up VMware
with Accelerator  backups to PDDE (Deduplication storage):

  1. Review the VMs in the environment and determine what OS / Application are the majority of the VMs. Determine the top 5 to 10 *types* of VM. (If using templates, determine which is the most often deployed manually). This task is unfortunately time consuming if this data point is not already being tracked. It is not immediately available as a metric in VSphere. 2. Find one example VM from each of the types, determined in the previous step. 3. Create a simple VMware policy, with manual client selection and backup the first example ONLY--(ONE Virtual Machine in the policy). **It is critical to this solution that only one (1) job run to PDDE at any given moment until this procedure is complete. By running a single job, the data is filtered through PDPlugin and then sent to Deduplication Storage one SO at a time, sequentially filling up containers from a single backup, ensuring that the SO's for at least one image are all adjacent. Since this has a high degree of commonality with other VMs in the environment, this data will be referenced extensively, and we will benefit during reads since a large amount of the data will be adjacent and contiguous. 4. Repeat for each client; do not start a new backup until the previous is complete. The initial Deduplication rates will increase on subsequent jobs and is not the goal at this point. The current goal is to "seed" the PDDE storage with single contiguous data streams. 5. When the last VM determined from step 2 above has completed its backup, this procedure is complete, and backups can be started according to either VMware Intelligent Policy, or multiple manually selected clients without issue with the Accelerator feature enabled with as many jobs and clients at once that is appropriate for the PDDE storage unit in the environment. 

title: HotAdd transport mode requirements for VMware VM backups
url: https://www.veritas.com/support/en_US/article.100046069.html
#### HotAdd transport mode requirements for VMware VM backups

It is suggested to consider the below options before using HotAdd transport
mode to backup and restore VMs. * The backup host VM must be created from the scratch (Not from any template or cannot be a clone of any VM). * The backup host VM must reside under the same data center where the VM to backup exist. * The backup host VM must have enough number of SCSI controllers to accommodate VMDKs from other VMs to be mounted. * Maximum 4 SCSI controllers can be attached to one backup host VM. A single SCSI controller can have a maximum of 15 disks attached. * HotAdd works only with virtual machines with SCSI disks and is not supported for backing up virtual machines with IDE disks. * To run multiple concurrent jobs totally for more than 15 disks, it is necessary to add more SCSI controllers to the HotAdd host. The maximum number of 4 SCSI controllers can be added to a HotAdd host, so a total of 60 devices are supported at the maximum. * HotAdd requires the VMware Backup Host to have access to datastores where the Virtual Machine being backed up resides. This essentially means: ESX where the VMware backup host is running should have access to datastores where the Virtual Machine being backed up resides. * HotAdd cannot be used if the VMFS block size of the datastore containing the virtual machine folder for the target virtual machine does not match the VMFS block size of the datastore containing the VMware Backup Host virtual machine. * For example, if you back up virtual disk on a datastore with 1MB blocks, the VMware Backup Host must also be on a datastore with 1MB blocks. * Restores using HotAdd on a Windows Server 2008 and above proxy require setting the SAN policy to OnlineAll. * If we are converting a physical machine to a virtual machine with the intention of using HotAdd to back up the virtual machine, do not use IDE controllers for any disks that are used during the conversion process. * The VMware backup host will need the ability to connect to TCP port 443 on the vCenter and TCP ports 443 and 902 on ESX/ESXi hosts while using HotAdd for backup/restores.

title: VMware with Accelerator backups experiencing performance issues
url: https://www.veritas.com/support/en_US/article.100032433.html
Accelerator optimization is not impacted, however the jobs take
more time to complete overall. **BPBKAR log** from the Linux VMware backup
host (a Windows VMware backup host does not capture these messages in the
BPBKAR log):

  `<4> vxms_shutdown: VxMS Performance stats: (../vxms_bridge.cpp:971)...<4>
vxms_shutdown: **FIML ReadOnly Time: 71910514280** , Size: 6057328640, Ops:
70645, **MB/s: 80.332** (../vxms_bridge.cpp:992)<4> vxms_shutdown: **ACCL
Checksum Time: 169154432** , Size: 15761408, Ops: 130, **MB/s: 88.8611**
(../vxms_bridge.cpp:994)<4> vxms_shutdown: **FIML Total Read Time:
72079668712** , Size: 6073090048, Ops: 70775, **MB/s:
80.3521**(../vxms_bridge.cpp:998)<4> vxms_shutdown: **FIML Write Time:
26070366911696** , Size: 6057328640, Ops: 70645, **MB/s: 0.221582**
(../vxms_bridge.cpp:1004)`

Note here that the read time is not the problem, but **BPBKAR** appears to be
waiting on **BPTM** , indicating a delay committing write operations. Segment Object (SO) spread (more SO's spread across more containers, also
know as Segment Locality) results in poor reads since they cannot be
optimized.


```

How many VMware vms can I back up at the same time on the same datastore?

## NetBackup for VMware best practices

The following are best practices for NetBackup for VMware:

  * For a more efficient backup, the NetBackup media server and the VMware backup host should be installed on the same host. * When creating virtual machines, use the same name for both host name and display name. If the policy's Primary VM identifier option is changed, the existing entries on the policy Clients tab still work. * VMware recommends that you run no more than four simultaneous backups of virtual machines that reside on the same datastore. * Successful VMware snapshots depend on the following:

    * The amount of I/O that occurs on the virtual machine datastore. Backups should be scheduled when relatively little I/O activity is expected. Reducing the number of simultaneous backups can also help. Limit access to the datastore per policy: Use the Limit jobs per policy
attribute in the NetBackup policy. Limit access to the datastore globally (across all policies): Use the Host
Properties Resource Limit screen. See [Setting global limits on the use of VMware resources](v47183490 "Setting
global limits on the use of VMware resources"). * The design of the I/O substructure that is associated with each virtual machine datastore. For correct I/O design and implementation, consult your VMware documentation. * Make sure that the VMware backup host has enough memory to handle the number of simultaneous backups that occur. * Include in a single NetBackup policy those virtual machines that use the same datastore. This practice lets you control the amount of backup-related I/O that occurs per datastore, to limit the backup effect on the target virtual machines. * NetBackup supports multiple backup hosts. When a single backup host is saturated with a backup process, another backup host can be added to increase backup throughput. * If a VM's disks are accessible to multiple ESX hosts, the disks can be accessed for backup or restore through any of the ESX hosts. The ESX host may or may not be the ESX host where the virtual machine is running or registered. All of the following must be accessible to each other and should have DNS configured:

    * The vCenter server. * All ESX hosts under the vCenter that have access to the VM's vmdk files.

title: VMware with Accelerator backups experiencing performance issues
url: https://www.veritas.com/support/en_US/article.100032433.html
The Accelerator option is synthesizing a Full VMware backup when
an Incremental is executed, and multiple reads of previous backups are slow
because they have to read from many different containers. The use of encryption had a contributing effect, and was originally thought to
be the main effect, but tests in a lab proved otherwise. This is thought to be tied to the initial backups, since most of the VMs in
this environment were deployed from the same few templates, so data change was
actually fairly low, but because the initial backups included 96 jobs all at
once, it was impossible to contain SOs from spreading across containers while
so many jobs were running at once. Reduce the occurrence of bad Segment
Locality with the following initial backup procedures when setting up VMware
with Accelerator  backups to PDDE (Deduplication storage):

  1. Review the VMs in the environment and determine what OS / Application are the majority of the VMs. Determine the top 5 to 10 *types* of VM. (If using templates, determine which is the most often deployed manually). This task is unfortunately time consuming if this data point is not already being tracked. It is not immediately available as a metric in VSphere. 2. Find one example VM from each of the types, determined in the previous step. 3. Create a simple VMware policy, with manual client selection and backup the first example ONLY--(ONE Virtual Machine in the policy). **It is critical to this solution that only one (1) job run to PDDE at any given moment until this procedure is complete. By running a single job, the data is filtered through PDPlugin and then sent to Deduplication Storage one SO at a time, sequentially filling up containers from a single backup, ensuring that the SO's for at least one image are all adjacent. Since this has a high degree of commonality with other VMs in the environment, this data will be referenced extensively, and we will benefit during reads since a large amount of the data will be adjacent and contiguous. 4. Repeat for each client; do not start a new backup until the previous is complete. The initial Deduplication rates will increase on subsequent jobs and is not the goal at this point. The current goal is to "seed" the PDDE storage with single contiguous data streams. 5. When the last VM determined from step 2 above has completed its backup, this procedure is complete, and backups can be started according to either VMware Intelligent Policy, or multiple manually selected clients without issue with the Accelerator feature enabled with as many jobs and clients at once that is appropriate for the PDDE storage unit in the environment. 

title: HotAdd transport mode requirements for VMware VM backups
url: https://www.veritas.com/support/en_US/article.100046069.html
#### HotAdd transport mode requirements for VMware VM backups

It is suggested to consider the below options before using HotAdd transport
mode to backup and restore VMs. * The backup host VM must be created from the scratch (Not from any template or cannot be a clone of any VM). * The backup host VM must reside under the same data center where the VM to backup exist. * The backup host VM must have enough number of SCSI controllers to accommodate VMDKs from other VMs to be mounted. * Maximum 4 SCSI controllers can be attached to one backup host VM. A single SCSI controller can have a maximum of 15 disks attached. * HotAdd works only with virtual machines with SCSI disks and is not supported for backing up virtual machines with IDE disks. * To run multiple concurrent jobs totally for more than 15 disks, it is necessary to add more SCSI controllers to the HotAdd host. The maximum number of 4 SCSI controllers can be added to a HotAdd host, so a total of 60 devices are supported at the maximum. * HotAdd requires the VMware Backup Host to have access to datastores where the Virtual Machine being backed up resides. This essentially means: ESX where the VMware backup host is running should have access to datastores where the Virtual Machine being backed up resides. * HotAdd cannot be used if the VMFS block size of the datastore containing the virtual machine folder for the target virtual machine does not match the VMFS block size of the datastore containing the VMware Backup Host virtual machine. * For example, if you back up virtual disk on a datastore with 1MB blocks, the VMware Backup Host must also be on a datastore with 1MB blocks. * Restores using HotAdd on a Windows Server 2008 and above proxy require setting the SAN policy to OnlineAll. * If we are converting a physical machine to a virtual machine with the intention of using HotAdd to back up the virtual machine, do not use IDE controllers for any disks that are used during the conversion process. * The VMware backup host will need the ability to connect to TCP port 443 on the vCenter and TCP ports 443 and 902 on ESX/ESXi hosts while using HotAdd for backup/restores.
